title: Amy Coney Barrett Closes Out Testimony, on Track for Senate Approval
summary: Republicans line up behind Supreme Court nominee while Democrats suggest she is a threat to widely accepted rights. WASHINGTON-Supreme Court nominee Amy Coney Barrett faced questions ranging from the constitutionality of Medicare to the extent of press freedom at her confirmation hearing Wednesday, but President Trump's choice to succeed the late Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg repeatedly said it would be improper to disclose her views on matters she said she could be called upon to decide.

title: No Improper Activity Seen in 'Unmasking' Requests Under Obama
summary: Trump and Republicans in Congress saw evidence of plot to spy on his incoming administration. A federal prosecutor's review found no improper activity by Obama administration officials who requested the identities of Americans whose names were redacted in classified intelligence reports around the time of the 2016 presidential election, two officials familiar with the matter said.

title: Recycled-Plastic Maker Loop Denies Short Seller's Accusations
summary: Short seller Hindenburg Research claimed Loop lied about its technology. Loop Industries Inc., which has attracted partnerships with big food-and-beverage companies, denied accusations by short seller Hindenburg Research that the company lied about its recyclable-plastic technology.

title: Joe Biden Raised $383 Million in September, Breaking Earlier Record
summary: Campaign says it has $432 million in the bank in the final weeks before Election Day. WASHINGTON-Democratic presidential nominee Joe Biden raised $383 million in September, surpassing the record-breaking haul he collected a month earlier in his campaign against President Trump.

title: China Drugmaker Gives Unproven Covid-19 Vaccine to Students Going Abroad
summary: State-owned Sinopharm is distributing doses outside of clinical trials; Western experts say China is moving too fast and endangering public. China is expanding distribution of its coronavirus vaccines outside of clinical trials, with a state-owned company offering them to students going abroad amid a campaign by officials to boost public confidence in homegrown inoculations.

title: Trump Campaigns in Iowa as Polls Show Tight Race
summary: President spent time in a state he won easily four years ago. Seeking to boost support in a state that has become an unexpected battleground, President Trump appeared at a rally in Iowa Wednesday night, declaring: "Nobody's going to do for Iowa what I did for Iowa."

title: Two Americans Held Hostage by Iran-Backed Forces in Yemen Set Free
summary: U.S. backs exchange, including the remains of a third American, for Houthi fighters in deal that Saudis hope will jump start peace talks in Yemen's civil war. Two Americans held hostage by Iran-backed Houthi militants in Yemen were freed on Wednesday as part of a U.S.-backed trade that returned more than 200 of the group's loyalists to the fractured Middle East country, according to U.S. and Saudi officials.

title: Albertsons Wins Bankruptcy Auction for Kings and Balducci's Stores
summary: A $96.4 million offer from Albertsons division Acme beats initial $75 million bid by investment firm TLI Bedrock. The bankrupt parent company of Kings Food Markets and Balducci's named Albertsons Cos. the winner at a chapter 11 auction for the supermarket operators with a $96.4 million cash bid.

title: Alabama Coach Nick Saban Tests Positive for Covid-19 as Virus Disrupts SEC
summary: The legendary coach's positive test results came as two conference games were postponed because of coronavirus outbreaks. After skating through three weeks of competition unscathed, the Southeastern Conference was rumbled by the coronavirus pandemic as Alabama's 68-year-old head coach Nick Saban tested positive for Covid-19 and two of the league's seven games this weekend were postponed after outbreaks on the Vanderbilt and Florida rosters.

title: TikTok Supplier Fastly Cuts Expectations, Cites Weakness at Video App
summary: The internet-content deliverer loses more than a quarter of its value after saying usage at largest customer fell short of views. Fastly Inc. lost more than a quarter of its market value late Wednesday after the internet content deliverer lowered its revenue guidance because of reduced use from its largest customer, the video-sharing app TikTok.

title: Vista Equity's Robert Smith Reaches Settlement With DOJ
summary: Billionaire is set to pay $140 million and admit liability for additional taxes owed but won't be prosecuted. Robert Smith, the billionaire chief executive of Vista Equity Partners, has reached a $140 million settlement with the Justice Department, ending a yearslong criminal tax probe, according to people familiar with the matter.

title: Suicide Accounts for Most Gun Deaths. A Libertarian Approach Could Help.
summary: Making it easier for individuals to opt for giving up their gun rights could greatly cut suicides-the most common type of gun fatality in the U.S.. On June 26, 2018, Donna Nathan killed herself in New Orleans with a gun that she had purchased earlier that morning, ending a 30-year battle with bipolar disorder and depression. Nathan fought right up until the end. In her last six months, she admitted herself three times for inpatient psychiatric treatment because she wanted to address her suicidal thoughts and prior impulsive suicide attempts.

title: What CIOs Can Learn From the Race to Understand Covid-19 Data
summary: Prepare data systems to evolve regularly, says ex-U. S. chief data scientist. Chief information officers can learn many lessons from the coronavirus pandemic when it comes to managing data, according to DJ Patil, a former U.S. chief data scientist, including the need to prepare for constant change and broadening who counts as data stakeholders.

title: Wells Fargo Fires Employees Who Applied for SBA Pandemic Loans
summary: Internal investigation found that as many as 125 employees made false representations in applying for Economic Injury Disaster Loans. Wells Fargo & Co. fired more than 100 employees for allegedly defrauding a federal pandemic-relief program.

title: Aaron Sorkin's 'Trial of the Chicago 7' Comes to Netflix
summary: Sacha Baron Cohen is among the stars of the new film that comes amid a wave of projects focusing on civil unrest. Among the characters in the new Netflix film, "The Trial of the Chicago 7," is a U.S. Attorney General who calls for a return to the homespun manners of his youth. But Aaron Sorkin who wrote and directed the starry film, which is set during the late 1960s, insisted that any similarities with the present weren't by design. "The script didn't change to mirror events," he said. "Events changed to mirror the script."

title: Facebook's Conservative Emergency
summary: A report shows how fake news fears are exploited to promote censorship.. The German Marshall Fund (GMF) is an influential think tank based in Washington, D.C., named for U.S. Secretary of State George Marshall's 1948 plan to help European countries resist Communism. What a shame that in 2020 the outfit is promoting political suppression of conservative news, with state media as a recommended replacement.

title: Amazon Cancels Shelby Steele
summary: The company won't stream a film on the 'real victimization of black America.'. As a documentary, "What Killed Michael Brown?" has everything going for it. Its subject is timely, about the pre-George Floyd killing of Michael Brown by a police officer that set off riots in Ferguson, Mo., in 2014.

title: California's Next Big Tax Gulp
summary: A ballot measure would repeal the business half of legendary Prop. 13.. Sooner or later California's public unions had to hit up the hoi polloi to pay for their pensions after soaking what's left of the state's millionaire class, and here they come.

title: The Supreme Court's Census Reprieve
summary: The Justices block an attempt to hijack Congressional reapportionment.. The Supreme Court on Tuesday wisely put the kibosh on a legal effort by progressive groups to usurp control over the decennial census and kick Congressional reapportionment into a Joe Biden Presidency. The Justices are sending an important message to lower courts to stay out of this political thicket.

title: TikTok Rivals Seek to Exploit U.S. Action, Lawyers Say in Court Filings
summary: Video-sharing app asks judge to stop U.S. from imposing measures that would essentially force a shutdown of TikTok's U.S. operations next month. WASHINGTON-The Trump administration's attempted ban on Chinese-owned TikTok threatens to devastate the video-sharing app's user base and competitive position, lawyers for the company argued Wednesday.

title: 'God in Gotham' Review: Spires and Skyscrapers
summary: Far from being a Sodom on the Hudson, New York was a center of religious dynamism throughout the 20th century.. Are you there, God? It's me, Manhattan.

title: Twitter Data-Breach Case Won't Be Resolved Before Year's End, Ireland's Regulator Says
summary: Eleven EU regulators objected to a proposed ruling in May, sparking a lengthy dispute-resolution process. European privacy regulators are unlikely to issue a final ruling on Twitter Inc.'s handling of a data breach disclosed in January 2019 before the end of this year, Ireland's data commissioner said Wednesday.

title: Trump Has No Time Left to Spare
summary: He finally showed some discipline at Monday's rally. Now he needs to keep it up.. The 2020 campaign has entered its stretch run. Though early voting just began, at least 14.9 million people have already cast a ballot. This points to an election turnout that will eclipse 2016's total of 138 million votes.

title: Democrats Assured ACA Would Come Before ACB
summary: California and the House asked the Supreme Court to fast-track's Texas' challenge to the law.. Democrats now claim they oppose Judge Amy Coney Barrett's confirmation because they fear she will overturn the Affordable Care Act in California v. Texas, which is scheduled for oral argument on Nov. 10. But the case is before the Supreme Court now only because Democrats insisted that the justices consider the case straightaway. Their rush precluded a more careful reconsideration that almost certainly would have preserved much or all of the law.

title: The Constitution Makes Beautiful Music
summary: My son's struggle with multiplication led to my rediscovery of 'Schoolhouse Rock.'. Autumn is here, which in my neck of the North Carolina woods means two things. First, nature's splendid beauty is on display in the turning of the leaves. Second, my fourth-grade son is wrestling with his multiplication tables.

title: Amy Coney Barrett's Christian Religiosity
summary: Sen. Dianne Feinstein was onto something worth talking about when she said, 'The dogma lives loudly within you.'. Sen. Dianne Feinstein won't ever repeat the phrase she made famous during Judge Amy Coney Barrett's 2017 appeals-court confirmation hearing: "The dogma lives loudly within you." That is a line worthy of a great drama, such as Robert Bolt's "A Man for All Seasons." It will remain the most memorable thing Sen. Feinstein ever said. And it should. The dogma lives loudly within you.

title: Notable & Quotable: Ted Cruz on Sheldon Whitehouse and His Friend, the Judge
summary: 'How did Mr. McConnell become a judge? Well, according to CQ Roll Call, he contributed about $500,000 to Democratic political committees.'. Sen. Ted Cruz at Judge Amy Coney Barrett's confirmation hearing Oct. 14:

title: Fed's Clarida Says Continuing Support Will Be Needed to Sustain Recovery
summary: Central bank's second-in-command says swift recovery shows how effective government and central bank actions have been.

title: United Airlines Hunkers Down for Long Air-Travel Drought
summary: Carrier says stockpiling cash and cutting costs are key to withstanding coronavirus pandemic. United Airlines Holdings Inc. said it is positioning itself to ride out a long downturn in air travel as a result of the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Pelosi, Mnuchin Disagree on Testing, Continue Stimulus Talks
summary: House speaker, Treasury secretary work to hash out policy disputes over another round of relief. WASHINGTON-House Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin continued to haggle over policies including testing strategy in their negotiations Wednesday over another coronavirus relief package, despite closing some distance over how much money to spend.

title: Fed Official Wonders Whether Treasury Market Can Handle Massive Issuance Alone
summary: Randal Quarles says the Fed may have to continue asset buying because markets are dealing with too many Treasurys to handle on their own. The Federal Reserve's point man on financial regulation said the Treasury market has grown so large that some level of central bank involvement may need to continue to ensure orderly trading conditions.

title: Amy Cooper Appears in Court for Calling 911 on Black Bird-Watcher
summary: Cooper, a white woman, also claimed the man had threatened to assault her, Manhattan prosecutors say. Amy Cooper, the white woman who falsely accused a Black bird-watcher in May of threatening her life in Central Park, was arraigned Wednesday in Manhattan on false reporting charges.

title: What Happened to the Economy Under Trump Before Covid and After
summary: Many achievements of the president's pre-pandemic economy have been wiped out. President Trump has sought to turn the focus of the November election toward the economy during the campaign's final stretch. His presidency has been characterized by two economies. While the first, which lasted until March, was good for millions of Americans, the Covid-19 era economy has been historically bad.

title: Barron Trump Tested Positive for Covid-19 Earlier This Month
summary: The first lady said she immediately had her son-the president's youngest child-tested when she and the president tested positive for Covid-19. Barron Trump, President Trump and first lady Melania Trump's 14-year-old son, tested positive for Covid-19 earlier this month and has since recovered, the first lady said Wednesday.

title: Gov. Cuomo Threatens to Withhold Funds from New York City, Other Covid-19 Hot Spots
summary: New York governor has been frustrated by reports of large gatherings at schools and religious occasions that violate new restrictions. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo threatened to withhold state funding from several municipalities including New York City, if officials there don't work harder to enforce social-distancing mandates the state imposed last week in coronavirus hot spots.

title: Meat Giant JBS's Owner Settles U.S. Corruption Charges
summary: J&F Investimentos will pay $128 million in agreement with U.S. authorities. SÃO PAULO-Brazil's J&F Investimentos, which controls the world's largest meatpacker, JBS SA, put an end to a long-running legal dispute in the U.S. over bribes it paid in Brazil, agreeing Wednesday to pay $128 million to settle the case.

title: Starbucks Is Linking Executive Pay to Diversity Targets
summary: The move comes amid intense discussion about representation in American companies and White House scrutiny of diversity-related targets. Starbucks has become the latest company to set new diversity goals, saying it plans to make antibias training mandatory for executives and tie their compensation to increasing minority representation in its workforce.

title: Macy's Names New CFO to Help Navigate Business Transformation, Pandemic
summary: Adrian Mitchell is set to join the department store operator on Nov. 2, replacing Felicia Williams. Macy's Inc. has hired a new permanent finance chief to help the department-store chain navigate its business transformation as the coronavirus pandemic continues to dent sales.

title: Illegal Border Crossings Rise Since Hitting Three-Year Low in April
summary: Though numbers fell steeply this fiscal year, last month was Border Patrol's busiest September since 2006. WASHINGTON-The number of migrants caught crossing the U.S.-Mexican border illegally rose for the fifth straight month in September, after the Trump administration earlier this year launched a pandemic policy allowing border agents to immediately expel anyone caught making such an attempt.

title: Europe Overtakes U.S. in New Cases of Covid-19
summary: Rising tide of infections on Continent has health authorities worried whether hospitals will hold. Europe has reached a tipping point in its fight to contain a second wave of the coronavirus, overtaking the U.S. in a key metric that tracks the virus's spread.

title: Stocks Slide as Stimulus Prospects Dim
summary: Investors are assessing risks tied to rising coronavirus infections and the lack of consensus on fresh stimulus spending. U.S. stocks fell again Wednesday, giving up earlier gains, as investors parsed earnings reports and the latest haggling by lawmakers on coronavirus aid.

title: Two Senior Officials Leave New York City Government
summary: Architects of Mayor Bill de Blasio's criminal-justice approach are latest high-profile departures. Two architects of New York Mayor Bill de Blasio's criminal-justice approach resigned, the latest high-profile officials to leave government as the city has struggled with the coronavirus pandemic.

title: The Teachers Union's Tiny New Enemy
summary: The behemoth National Education Association seeks to squash popular pandemic microschools.. Why is the elephant afraid of the mouse? Your child's teacher may not know, but his union does. In September the National Education Association, America's largest labor union, produced an internal "opposition report" on Prenda, a tiny Arizona-based "microschool" provider. I obtained a copy of the document, which picks apart Prenda's vulnerabilities but also offers a warning: "The Opposition Report has documented widespread support for micro-schools." Education Secretary Betsy DeVos is expected to receive a presentation about Prenda on Thursday at a charter school in Phoenix.

title: In Newburyport, Million-Dollar Homes Are Flying Off the Shelves
summary: Resume Subscription. "Newburyport was part of my childhood," said Gina Weishaupt.

title: Along the Streets of Newburyport, Mass.
summary: A city turns on the charm.. We are delighted that you'd like to resume your subscription.

title: Pandemic Spending Threatens Brazilian Stocks' Hard-Won Climb
summary: Brasília fueled rally in shares by cutting interest rates, but efforts to fight Covid-19 could derail that. Brazil's government spurred big gains in stocks in recent years by pursuing austerity policies that allowed its central bank to cut interest rates to all-time lows. Now, some worry efforts to fight Covid-19 could unravel all that.

title: Normalcy? Not From a Biden Administration
summary: If Joe Biden's Democratic Party eliminates fracking and fossil fuels via a Green New Deal, makes D.C. a new state and packs the Supreme Court, how exactly is that a return to normalcy?. Regarding Peggy Noonan's "Biden, Pence and the Wish for Normalcy" (Declarations, Oct. 10): If Joe Biden's Democratic Party eliminates fracking and fossil fuels via a Green New Deal, makes D.C. a new state to ensure a permanent Democratic Senate majority and packs the Supreme Court to enact left-wing policies that would never pass through legislation, how exactly would that be a return to normalcy?

title: Copyright Law and iPhones Too Easy to Use
summary: Authors do have a right to stop publication and sale of their books under the law of copyright. They don't enforce those rights, though, precisely because it's in their interest to allow publication and sale to happen.. In "Is Your iPhone Too Easy to Use?" (op-ed, Oct. 7), Kent Walker and Brad Smith worry that if the Supreme Court allows copyright on certain aspects of computer software, the result would stop progress. The authors fail to understand how and why copyright rights are enforced.

title: Mental-Health Responders Can Help Police
summary: While a psychiatrist is unlikely to accompany police, responders trained in mental health can and should.. In "Coronavirus Delivers an October Surprise" (Declarations, Oct. 3), Peggy Noonan dismisses as "ridiculous" Joe Biden's suggestion during the debate that a psychiatrist respond to 911 calls involving persons with serious mental-health problems. The idea isn't as ridiculous as you think. While a psychiatrist is unlikely to accompany police, responders trained in mental health can and should. In Manchester, N.H., the police have joined forces with local social-service agencies to implement Acert: Adverse Childhood Experiences Response Team. When police respond to a domestic-violence call or a drug-related call, and so on, there are often children present who have witnessed these events, and are likely exposed to other social, physical and psychological circumstances that can have long-term consequences for their development. Trained child advocates may either ride along with the police on these calls or within 24-48 hours will visit the premises to talk with the parents, make referrals for counseling, etc. This approach is actually common in many countries, such as Australia.

title: Adams Considered People's Vote in 1800 and Ignored It
summary: Is there something magical about the time before an election that makes it inappropriate for a Supreme Court nomination?. Can Sen. Joe Manchin please explain the difference between a "before the election" appointment and an "after the election" appointment (Letters, Oct. 12)? Is there something magical about the time before an election that makes it inappropriate for a Supreme Court nomination? Or is the left wing arguing that the people should have their say in the election before any appointments are made? Because if it's this second argument, then the Journal is making an excellent point about the John Adams nomination and confirmation of John Marshall. Despite having lost the election, President Adams still appointed the new chief justice. President Adams carried out his duties as president until the last day of his term. He didn't concern himself with the results of the election of 1800. He was fulfilling the will of the people as expressed in the election of 1796.

title: Racism and the Only Right Way of Thinking
summary: The school board's position that those who challenge the district's policies and protocols are resisting equity and maintaining white supremacy has destroyed any possibility for dialogue.. I appreciate the article "Race Debate Divides Illinois School District" (U.S. News, Oct. 7) about equity in Evanston's schools. I have been watching the story unfold for months. It has been deeply disheartening to see an area that needs meaningful change to be polarized as racist or antiracist. The school board's position that those who challenge the district's policies and protocols are resisting equity and maintaining white supremacy has destroyed any possibility for dialogue and limited the change that can be effected. Saying this in Evanston earns you the label of racist. It is an easy way to dismiss a voice.

title: Business Roundtable Is Changing as the Times Change
summary: Support for capitalism is under threat because too many Americans believe that our system benefits only wealthy shareholders.. Last year, in overturning an old policy statement that defined a corporation's principal purpose as maximizing shareholder value, the CEOs of Business Roundtable asserted that their enterprises exist to serve all their stakeholders. The CEOs declared that, along with generating long-term value for shareholders, success requires sustaining the trust of customers, investing in employees, dealing fairly with suppliers and supporting the communities in which they operate.

title: Wells Fargo Earnings Drop 56%
summary: While the bank's results improved from second quarter, shares fell sharply. Wells Fargo & Co. said Wednesday that its third-quarter profit fell 56%, though the bank signaled it was prepared for a wave of soured loans.

title: Bank of America Profit Falls 16%
summary: Lender says it is well prepared to weather the coronavirus recession. Bank of America Corp.'s profit fell 16% in the third quarter, though the bank indicated that it is well prepared to weather the coronavirus recession.

title: Goldman Sachs Profit Nearly Doubles
summary: Bank's profit nearly doubles; trading revenue rose 29% from a year ago. Goldman Sachs Group Inc. said Wednesday its third-quarter profit nearly doubled, the latest confirmation that even in a pandemic and a recession, Wall Street can still make money.

title: Wisconsin Judge Temporarily Blocks State Order on Taverns
summary: Judge asks state health officials to defend their order in hearing next week. A Wisconsin judge has temporarily halted new restrictions on capacity at bars, restaurants and other indoor spaces as the state continues to see a surge of Covid-19 cases and hospitalizations.

title: Broadway Is Dark, but a Famed Theater District Restaurant Is Turning on the Lights
summary: Joe Allen, a 46th Street mainstay, plans to reopen Thursday for the first time since March. For more than 50 years, Joe Allen has been one of the quintessential gathering places in New York City's theater district, a restaurant where Broadway industry titans and show-goers alike dine and drink before or after performances.

title: Second Covid-19 Vaccine Approved by Russia
summary: Green light for third vaccine expected later this year, as Moscow looks to be a major player in race to end pandemic. MOSCOW-Russia approved a second Covid-19 vaccine and said it was closing in on a third as Moscow attempts to establish itself as a major player in the global race to end the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Collusion Theory Promoters Attack New Biden Story
summary: Media rivals target New York Post report on Burisma.. News consumers should be gratified to know that the New York Times has decided it will demand the highest journalistic standards-at least from its crosstown rivals. Just three days after a Times writer formally announced that the newspaper is transitioning "from the stodgy paper of record into a juicy collection of great narratives," Times staff is now attacking the juiciest narrative of the 2020 campaign.

title: Poor Nations Get 6-Month Extension on Suspended Debt Payments
summary: Group of 20 extends program to allow low-income debtors to focus on fighting coronavirus. The world's largest economies extended a program that allows the poorest countries to suspend their debt payments so they can focus their fiscal resources on the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Amazon Expands NFL Coverage With Playoff Game
summary: Amazon Prime Video to carry one new wildcard playoff game, which also will be available on ViacomCBS platforms. Amazon.com Inc. has struck a deal with the National Football League to stream a playoff game this season, people familiar with the matter said.

title: How One Winery Is Coping With the Napa Fire
summary: Jeff Smith of Hourglass Winery has deep roots in the region. Facing the devastation of the Glass Fire to his property and community, he sounds a remarkable note of resilience.. IT WAS JUST after 4 in the morning on Sunday, Sept. 27, when Napa winemaker Jeff Smith got a call from his neighbor, telling him to get out of his house. The nearby hills were ablaze and the wind was whipping the fire in the direction of their homes. The Glass Fire, as it came to be known, had just started near Napa's Howell Mountain.

title: Supply-Chain Tech Firm E2open to Go Public in SPAC Deal
summary: The software provider is capping an acquisition spree with a reverse-merger agreement, bypassing traditional IPO process. Supply-chain software provider E2open LLC plans to go public through an agreement with a blank-check company, making it the latest in a stream of companies bypassing the traditional path to a Wall Street listing.

title: Someone Paid $32 Million for a Dinosaur. I Swear It Wasn't Me.
summary: A mystery buyer collects a magnificent T. rex fossil at auction-what do they do with it now?. Someone bought a dinosaur the other day for $32 million, but as of yet we don't know who. The exact price was $31.8 million, and it was for a 40-foot-long Tyrannosaurus rex fossil named Stan, anonymously bought in an auction at Christie's. I assume the price includes tax. I'm not sure about shipping. For $31.8 million, you have to figure they'd throw in shipping. But who knows these days.

title: 'Des' Review: Hunting Down a Killer's Victims
summary: A series on Sundance Now stars David Tennant as a real-life serial murderer who confesses to his crimes, leaving the police to locate and identify the men he killed.. Dennis Nilsen, the focus of everyone's attention in the fact-based "Des," is a lot of things-a Scotsman, an ex-policeman, a fan of The Who. A social Darwinist he's not. "It's really a disease," he says, regarding the drug addiction that's driven so many to the streets of '70s-'80s London. "Very sad. Bloody government doesn't do a thing for 'em." Des, as he's called, doesn't actually utter the words "public service," but he would like the police to recognize the contribution he's made to the general welfare, having killed at least a dozen of those lonely, homeless, struggling young men.

title: 'The Age of Nature' Review: Back From the Brink
summary: PBS's documentary series focuses on humanity's efforts to rehabilitate environments around the globe spoiled by war and industry.. The state of the environment as approached by television frequently becomes a subject fraught with terror, horror, guilt, forbidding carbon footprints and intimations of imminent incineration. But "The Age of Nature" is not just a beautifully made series, it's also a surprisingly joyful one. It's about rehabilitation-how humans are correcting environmental outrages from Panama to Mozambique to Central China to Yellowstone Park-and how forgiving Mother Nature can be if we just pay her some affectionate attention. The mixed message, of course, is that you're tempted to push mom till you push her too far. But to judge by the series, we haven't quite done it yet.

title: Oil Recovery Expected to Falter Though Supply Glut Shrinks
summary: IEA says global oil supply fell in September to 9% below the pre-pandemic average of 2019. The world is burning through the oil supply glut that threatened to cripple the energy industry a few months ago, but spiraling coronavirus infection numbers are putting the recovery in jeopardy, the International Energy Agency said Wednesday.

title: What to Watch: Political Picks for Election Season
summary: Political junkies share their favorite films and series about the intricacies of politics. It's election season, which means politics is on the brain-and on our screens.

A Chicago heir to a clothing-manufacturing fortune was so inspired by the House of Tomorrow in the city's 1933-34 Century of Progress International Exposition that she asked its architect, George Keck, to build her a private residence.

title: Democrats Once Seen as Long Shots Are Now Contenders for Senate

title: Handbags Aren't Dead. Four You'll Love for Fall.
summary: As we re-enter society, bags are relevant again. But germs and extreme commutes have complicated life-and teeny totes and hard-to-clean suede no longer make sense. Here, fall carryalls for our new normal.. AS WE cautiously venture into the world again, handbags have regained relevance. But a new wariness of germs has changed our shopping criteria. So, too, have extreme commutes, especially for new suburbanites returning to city offices. The small, hard-to-clean styles we've been storing in the closet since March no longer make sense. We require purses that can withstand antiseptic wipes; carry our essentials-from laptops to yoga mats-on those long train rides to work; or add comfort and convenience to our WFH experience.

title: Building Up Their Memory
summary: The Memorial to Enslaved Laborers at the University of Virginia honors the thousands of slaves who constructed the school, many of whom remain unidentified.. Charlottesville, Va.

title: Day-Care Centers Are Very Low Risk for Covid-19 Transmission, Study Says
summary: Paper adds new evidence that young children aren't major vectors in coronavirus transmission. Children in day-care programs present virtually no risk of transmitting Covid-19 to adults, according to a new Yale University study of more than 57,000 U.S. child-care providers.

title: Covid-19 Cases Are Rising in More Than 40 States
summary: European countries also battle surge in infections. The spread of the coronavirus appeared to be accelerating this week in the U.S. with a key indicator in 44 of the 50 states and Washington, D.C. flashing an "ominous" warning sign Tuesday, a health official said.

title: Goldman Sachs Adds Polish to Trading
summary: The trading desk at Goldman Sachs is getting more efficient with capital. When it comes to Wall Street trading, Goldman Sachs Group is doing more with less.

title: WeChat Threatens Free Speech
summary: The defense of the Chinese social-media app gets it precisely backward.. The Trump administration is pressing ahead with efforts to ban WeChat , the Chinese social-media app, appealing a preliminary injunction awarded in September to the WeChat Users Alliance. There is good reason to view this group, a self-described collection of "ordinary WeChat users" upset by the government's ban, with skepticism. Its lawyers include two from DeHeng Law, a firm that was once owned by the Chinese state and remains a close partner of Beijing's.

title: Trump, Biden to Hold Dueling TV Town Halls Thursday
summary: After the cancellation of the planned second debate, the two candidates will talk to voters at the same time-in different cities, on different networks. President Trump and former Vice President Joe Biden will appear in town hall forums Thursday night at the same time on different television networks, an unusual arrangement after a planned debate was canceled.

title: Early Voting in Texas Breaks Records
summary: Many polling stations had long lines on Tuesday, the first day of early voting in the state. AUSTIN, Texas-Counties across Texas broke their own records for early voter turnout on Tuesday, the first day of in-person voting.

title: Ann Taylor Parent Gets $35 Million Offer for Tween Brand Justice
summary: IHL Group proposes to acquire the brand out of bankruptcy from Ascena Retail. Ascena Retail Group Inc., the parent company of Ann Taylor and Lane Bryant, got a $35 million offer to buy tween chain Justice out of bankruptcy and turn it into a primarily online brand.

title: What Happens to the Musicians When the Orchestra Music Stops?
summary: After years of music training, performers see jobs in classical venues and theaters suddenly dry up; 'no one expects an entire field to disappear'. Julia McLean took decades of music lessons, spent thousands of hours practicing and coped with constant grueling competition, and in January it all paid off. She became a full-time viola player for the Indianapolis Symphony Orchestra.

title: Trump Stresses Economic Record in Virtual Speech
summary: President says Biden administration would destroy recovery. President Trump cast the November election as a choice between "historic prosperity" and a "steep depression," as he seeks to turn the focus toward the economy and away from the pandemic in the campaign's final stretch.

title: New York Regulator Urges Oversight for Social-Media Giants
summary: Agency issues recommendations for new regulator in wake of Twitter hack. New York's top financial watchdog said a dedicated regulator should oversee large social-media platforms, which should also be designated as systemically important, following a successful cyberattack on Twitter Inc. during the summer.

title: Pilgrim's Pride Reaches Plea Deal on Chicken Price-Fixing Allegations
summary: Second-largest U.S. chicken processor to pay $110.5 million fine. Chicken processor Pilgrim's Pride Corp. said it has agreed to a plea deal with the U.S. Justice Department to resolve price-fixing charges, and will pay a fine of $110.5 million.

title: 5 Fall Camping Getaways-From Effortless to Truly Adventurous
summary: For hikers-and campers-of varying skills, New York's Adirondack Park is an easy place to immerse yourself in wilderness. Plus four other more secluded nature escapes in Mississippi, New Mexico and more.. I WANTED TO escape into a real wilderness. Can you blame me? By September, after more than six months of Covid-induced restrictions and confinement, I was starved for a heady dose of nature. But I wanted to cap a pleasantly strenuous day of hiking with a shower, dinner at a cafe and no worries about pitching a tent.

title: Court Extends Virginia's Voter-Registration Deadline
summary: Website went down Tuesday after utilities work accidentally cut a fiber-optic cable. A federal judge extended through Thursday Virginia's voter-registration deadline, after the state's voter-registration website temporarily went offline Tuesday because of what officials said was an accidentally severed fiber-optic cable.

title: Goodbye, Sunny Florida. Hello, Frigid Winter. Covid Strands Canadian Snowbirds

title: UnitedHealth Profit Declines, Reflecting Return to More Usual Health-Care Levels
summary: Commercial membership drops, reflecting loss of some employer-based insurance during the economic downturn. UnitedHealth Group Inc.'s profit declined after outsize results in the previous quarter, as health care returned closer to normal levels after a dramatic pandemic-related pause in the spring and early summer.

title: Apple's iPhone 12: Sizing Up the 12, 12 Pro, 12 Pro Max and 12 Mini

summary: Energy Harbor asked to turn over documents as federal prosecutors investigate nature of company's payments to Ohio lawmaker. summary: Retailers describe cat-and-mouse games with police as they try to stay open, and vow to defy further closures. summary: Resume Subscription. Austin homeowners Michelle Lee, 49, and her husband, John Wallingford, 50, and their two children, watched as the finishing touches were put on their 610-square-foot backyard casita in the city's historic Hyde Park neighborhood.

title: Indonesia Weighs Approving Chinese Covid-19 Vaccines for Emergency Use
summary: The world's fourth most-populous country is moving toward aligning itself with Beijing's approach on vaccination. title: Football's Most Essential Workers During a Pandemic: Long Snappers
summary: The most specialized-and most easily ignored-player on the field has become invaluable during a season when roster depth has taken on added importance. The University of South Florida learned the hard way who the most essential workers in football during the pandemic are: long snappers.

title: Barr's Justice Department Touts Fighting Gun Violence as Election Approaches
summary: Attorney general's supporters see decisiveness, while critics call it inappropriate aid for Trump's re-election effort. Attorney General William Barr had a message for the dozens of U.S. attorneys gathered in a hotel conference room in Alexandria, Va., last month: With just weeks left before the November election and the end of President Trump's first term, they should push hard on federal gun-crime cases and prosecutions of violent demonstrators.

title: U.K.'s MI5 Steps Up Effort to Protect Covid-19 Vaccine Research
summary: Intelligence agency's new boss says it has shared knowledge on toxic chemicals to help with coronavirus studies. LONDON-The new head of MI5, the U.K.'s domestic intelligence service, said the agency had shared knowledge about the dispersal of toxic chemicals in droplets to aid scientists studying the coronavirus as he outlined efforts to protect the integrity of research into a Covid-19 vaccine.

title: The Verdict on Trump's Economic Stewardship, Before Covid and After
summary: Through last year, growth and a strong job market lifted many Americans, including less-skilled workers. The pandemic reversed that, and the path back to prosperity is uncertain.. Donald Trump has presided over two economies during his time in office.

title: Slack's Latest Collaboration Falls Flat on Its Feet
summary: Twitter users see Slack's new collaboration with old-school clothier Cole Haan as an embarrassment of tech's riches. Slack 's ticker symbol is "WORK," not "PLAY."

title: With This Sauce in the Fridge, You Always Have a Meal Ready to Go
summary: Lush and deeply savory, this Lao-style roast-tomato jeow is a classic dip for vegetables. But there are so many delicious ways to deploy it.. THIS DIPPING SAUCE is a particular favorite of chef Donny Sirisavath's. Known as jeow mak len in Lao cuisine, it takes advantage of late-season tomatoes, which roast along with garlic, jalapeños, onions and Thai chiles to produce a complex, concentrated flavor. A brief char under the broiler lends a hint of smoke. Coarsely mashed, the result is a lush, flavorful sauce.

title: The NFL Tries to Prevent Its Own Covid-19 Second Wave
summary: Executives say they fear protocol fatigue, especially from teams that fall out of contention, could set in after months of broad adherence to safety precautions. The Tennessee Titans played a football game Tuesday night, and there was a phenomenal sigh of relief from the NFL. It didn't matter that the Titans beat the Buffalo Bills, 42-16, to improve to 4-0. The Titans were marooned playing the NFL's second Tuesday game since 1946 (when a team called the Boston Yanks took the field) because Tennessee was home to the NFL's first coronavirus outbreak.

title: Airlines Pitch Frequent-Flier Mile Deals to Wary Travelers
summary: Carriers are boosting awards travel with offers not seen in years-will it be enough to bring back nervous passengers?. Besides wearing a mask on an airplane, there's one other thing you should definitely do if you are traveling this fall or over the holidays: Use your miles.

title: Apple Counts on 5G to Boost iPhone Fortunes in China
summary: Late to the next-generation smartphone market, Apple looks to win back fans in China despite trade tensions with U.S.. Apple Inc. is playing catch-up in China with the launch of its first 5G-enabled iPhones, seeking to supercharge uneven sales in the company's second-biggest market-where homegrown rivals dominate.

title: Are Blankets the New Going-Out Accessory?
summary: From Sarah Jessica Parker's monogrammed Burberry poncho to Norma Kamali's Sleeping Bag Coat, fashion has long embraced blanket-inspired styles. During a time when most socializing takes place outdoors, would you wear one outside the house?. Blankets, a symbol of coziness and warmth usually relegated to the indoors, can also be a great piece to layer for fall and winter outfits. Though temperatures are just starting to drop in New York City, WSJ. staffers have spotted a few in the wild-mostly while outdoor dining, which New York City recently extended permanently. (It was originally set to expire ahead of the winter months, on October 31.) For the first time in recent history, the preferred environment for socializing has become "anywhere outside." And during a pandemic and period of worldwide unrest, most people are seeking comfort more than ever. As a replacement for the timeworn going-out top-obviously better suited to the indoors-the going-out blanket suddenly makes sense.

title: Pandemic Response Will Drive Up Global Public Debt to a Record, IMF Says
summary: Governments around the world have committed $11.7 trillion, bringing debt close to 100% of global output this year. title: Covid-19 Travel Bubbles Were Set to Restore Flying but Haven't Taken Off
summary: International passenger volumes remain a fraction of pre-pandemic levels in the Asia-Pacific region as countries maintain containment measures. title: As Supreme Court Case on Affordable Care Act Looms, GOP Divided on How-and Whether-to Replace It
summary: Some Republicans are playing down the possibility that the high court will invalidate the health law, while others believe the party should emphasize its ideas for a replacement. title: BlackRock Bets on U.K. Electric-Vehicle Startup Arrival With $118 Million Investment
summary: U.K.-based manufacturer develops electric-powered city buses and vans, saying its vehicles can travel up to 300 miles without recharging. title: Arbor Refuels With Fresh $1.67 Billion for Food and Beverage Deals
summary: Chicago-based Arbor Investments has closed its fifth buyout fund and second mezzanine debt fund. title: Should Fiscal Policy Get More Chinese?
summary: New IMF research suggests the rich world substantially increase public investment. China spends too much on infrastructure. The U.S. and some other wealthy countries, it is widely accepted, invest too little. Now the International Monetary Fund, long a champion of fiscal rectitude, is suggesting that rich countries inch a bit further in China's direction by substantially increasing public investment.

title: Apparel's Next Hot Destination Could Be Target or Walmart
summary: Levi's partnership with Target looks promising. Target , Walmart and Tractor Supply Co. might not seem like the coolest places to sell apparel, but brands can't afford to be picky these days.

summary: Ten weeks into his job, Dr. Dave Chokshi is grappling with rapid testing and contact tracing as case counts rise. When Dave A. summary: Despite months of careful protocols, national-team meetups turn players from virus hotspots into traveling vectors for infection. He stood up at one end of the packed table, turned his phone on the two dozen players, and blasted out a group selfie to his 88 million followers on Twitter.

If remote working really takes hold, though, the owners of out-of-town offices may have more to worry about.
